Award.AwardTitle: Meteorological Analysis and Support for the Pacific Atmospheric Sulfur Experiment
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the key meteorological aspects of the Pacific Atmospheric Sulfur Experiment (PASE) will be investigated, using available meteorological data and analyses, satellite images and other data, data from the NSF/NCAR C-130, and retrospective and climatological data. These aspects include dynamical and thermodynamic controls on the structure of the convective boundary layer in which the sulfur flux and budget observations will be made, the basin-wide to synoptic scale wind distributions that control Equatorial upwelling and the resultant primary productivity which initiates the efflux of DMS, the structure and propagation of atmospheric waves that dominate the progression from cloud-free to cloudy conditions, and the occurrence and manifestations of the Southern Oscillation and El Nino. The PI will also be the mission meteorologist for PASE, providing analysis and forecasting support to the investigators during the field campaign. Meteorological charts, satellite images, and other needed products will be assembled and sent to the field site via the internet and/or facsimile transmission. After the field campaign, a comprehensive meteorological analysis will be developed for the area of the observations, using data and techniques parallel to those enumerated above. Also, a retrospective study of meteorological conditions during prior sulfur budget studies near Christmas Island will be carried out.

Broader impacts of this project include support for a graduate student with interdisciplinary interests at the boundary between meteorology and atmospheric chemistry. There will also be outreach efforts in secondary schools in Narragansett, Rhode Island and on the island of Kiritimati (Christmas Island).

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of the Pacific Atmospheric Sulfur Project we investigated the structure of the atmospheric boundary layer over the equatorial central Pacific Ocean. We provided meteoroloigcal analysis and guidance as part of the flight planning effort during the field phase of the program. We participated in an outreach education effort for local middle and high school students, demonstrating the type and significance of observations carried out on the instrumented aircraft, the NCAR C-130. In the analysis phase of the program we used aircraft-observed, satellite remote sensing and numerical meteorological model results to refine our understanding of the relationship between parts of the boundary layer.

As shown in the Figure, the lowest layer of the atmosphere is well mixed, heated by conduction of heat from the ocean surface. The latent heat transported by evaporated water can be released in clouds which form in and may extend above the buffer layer. The mean mixed layer temperature was steady during the period observed, as was the sea surface temperature. The fluxes of sensible and latent heat were thus also steady. The mixed layer depth was ~500 m, and the intermittently turbulent buffer layer was typically 1000 m deep. A weak temperature inversion separated these layers. The Trade Wind Inversion at the top of the buffer layer varied in strength somewhat, but was always stronger than the inversion at the top of the mixed layer. We developed diagnostic criteria to determine the mixed layer depth, based on data from vertical profiles. We estimated the Monin-Obukhov length scale, L, using profile data and surface flux estimates. The ratio of the mixed layer depth to L varied from -1.8 to -11.7 with a mean value of -5.3. These small, negative values indicate weak convective instability.; this is consistent with the observed scarcity of clouds and the presence of weakly-organized horizontal roll vortices. We estimated budgets of thermodynamic energy using high-resolution thermodynamic and wind data observed on the aircraft. We found a slight variation in the heating of the atmosphere by latent heat excahnge. The entrainment rate (flux of air into the mixed layer) was estimated using multiple thermodynamic variables. The result indicate a wide variation in the utility and consistency of the entrainment rates. The potential temperature and virtual potential temperature estimates generally don't show a significant jump across the interface, and the estimates are uncertain. The water vapor itself is more useful. Ozone-derived entrainment velocities are widely variable, because the ozone distribution above the mixed layer is heterogeneous. Sulfur dioxide is a poor tracer of exchange, both because of its short lifetime and its solubility. We found DMS to be the best tracer of the entrinment process. The entrainment rate estimates for DMS here are higher than in earlier studies, consistent with the high DMS flux values. The estimated entrainment velocities for each flight were always larger than the sum of the estimated large-scale vertical velocity (the subsidence) and the local time rate of change of the mixed layer depth. The reason for this disagreement remains a topic of investigation. Direct estimates of the thermodynamic fluxes were extrapolated downward toward the surface from the lowest fligth levels, and the values compared with estimates from the bulk parmeterization formulas commonly used in the marine environment. The snesible and latent heat fluxes were smaller than given by the bulk formulas, but the two methods agrees almost perfectly for the momentum flux (drag). This conrroborates earlier indications that the 'drag coefficient' used in bulk estimates may not be applicable to the estimation of the corresponding heat fluxes when the static stability is not neutral (that is, the layer is not very well mixed).
